Input¶

Downloading data¶

helper.download_file(url, direc, folder, extract=False)[source]¶

Download a file with url string url into directory direc/folder. If extract == True, extract the .zip or tar.gz file into the directory and delete the .zip or tar.gz file.

Parameters:
  • url (string) – the URL of the file you want to download
  • direc (string) – the directory relative to the script where you want to save
  • folder (string) – a folder in directory direc you want to save into
  • extract (bool) – if the file is compressed as zip or tar.gz, extract it

Accessing downloaded data : the DataFactory class¶

class datafactory.DataFactory[source]¶

This class contains several static methods that fetch and return raw data downloaded prevously by download_file(). These data are located in the data/continent subdirectory of the CSLVR root directory, where continent is currently either antarctica or greenland.

Each one of the static methods defined here return a dict of parameters needed by the DataInput class for conversion to the FEniCS code used by CSLVR.

  • pyproj_Proj – the geographical projection Proj instance associated with this data
  • map_western_edge – the Western-most edge of the data in projection coordinates
  • map_eastern_edge – the Eastern-most edge of the data in projection coordinates
  • map_southern_edge – the Southern-most edge of the data in projection coordinates
  • map_northern_edge – the Northern-most edge of the data in projection coordinates
  • nx – the number of x divisions of the data
  • ny – the number of y divisions of the data
  • dataset – the name of the dataset
  • continent – the continent of the datset
static get_ant_measures(res=450)[source]¶

Antarctica Measures surface velocity data. This function creates a new data field with key mask that is 1 where velocity measurements are present and 0 where they are not.

You will have to download the data and manually place it in the cslvr_root_dir/data/antarctica directory.

The keys of the dictionary returned by this function are :

  • vx – \(x\)-component of velocity
  • vy – \(y\)-component of velocity
  • v_err – velocity error
  • mask – observation mask
Parameters:res (int) – resolution of the data, may be either 450 or 900
Return type:dict
static get_bamber(thklim=0.0)[source]¶

Greenland Bamber topography data.

You will have to download the data from the authors and manually place it in the cslvr_root_dir/data/greenland directory.

The keys of the dictionary returned by this function are :

  • B – basal topography height
  • S – surface topography height
  • H – ice thickness
  • Herr – ice thickness error
  • Bo – basal topography height before imposing thklim
  • mask – ice shelf mask (1 where shelves, 0 where grounded)
  • mask_orig – original ice mask from the data
Parameters:thklim (float) – minimum-allowed ice thickness
Return type:dict
static get_bedmachine(thklim=0.0)[source]¶

Greenland Bedmachine geometry.

You will have to download the data and manually (from here) and place it in the cslvr_root_dir/data/greenland directory.

The keys of the dictionary returned by this function are :

  • B – basal topography height
  • S – surface topography height
  • H – ice thickness
  • Bo – basal topography height before imposing thklim
  • mask – ice shelf mask (1 where shelves, 0 where grounded)
  • mask_orig – original ice mask from the data
Parameters:thklim (float) – minimum-allowed ice thickness
Return type:dict
static get_bedmap1(thklim=0.0)[source]¶

Antarctica Bedmap 1 data. This function converts the geothermal-heat flux data from J s-1 m-2 to that used by CSLVR, J a-1 m-2, and the surface temperature data from degrees Celsius to degrees Kelvin. The parameter thklim sets the minimum allowed ice thickness.

This data is downloaded by executing the script cslvr_root/scripts/download_antarctica_data.py

The keys of the dictionary returned by this function are :

  • B – basal topography
  • S – surface topography
  • T – surface temperature
  • acca – accumulation/ablation function “a”
  • accr – accumulation/ablation function “r”
  • ghffm – Fox-Maule geothermal-heat flux
  • ghfsr – Shapiro-Ritzwoller geothermal-heat flux
Parameters:thklim (float) – minimum-allowed ice thickness
Return type:dict
static get_bedmap2(thklim=0.0)[source]¶

Antarctica Bedmap 2 topography data.

This data is downloaded by executing the script cslvr_root/scripts/download_antarctica_data.py

The keys of the dictionary returned by this function are :

  • B – basal topography height
  • S – surface topography height
  • H – ice thickness
  • mask – ice shelf mask
  • rock_mask – rock outcrop mask
  • b_uncert – basal-topography uncertainty
  • coverage – is a binary grid showing the distribution of ice thickness data used in the grid of ice thickness
  • gl04c_WGS84 – gives the values (as floating point) used to convert from heights relative to WGS84 datum to heights relative to EIGEN-GL04C geoid (to convert back to WGS84, add this grid)
Parameters:thklim (float) – minimum-allowed ice thickness
Return type:dict
static get_gimp()[source]¶

Greenland Ice Mapping Project surface topography data.

You will have to download the data and manually place it in the cslvr_root_dir/data/greenland directory.

The keys of the dictionary returned by this function are :

  • S – surface topography height
Return type:dict
static get_gre_measures()[source]¶

Greenland Measures surface velocity data. This function creates a new data field with key mask that is 1 where velocity measurements are present and 0 where they are not.

You will have to download the data from the authors and manually place it in the cslvr_root_dir/data/greenland directory.

The keys of the dictionary returned by this function are :

  • vx – \(x\)-component of velocity
  • vy – \(y\)-component of velocity
  • ex – \(x\)-component of velocity error
  • ey – \(y\)-component of velocity error
  • mask – observation mask
Return type:dict
static get_gre_qgeo_fox_maule()[source]¶

Greenland Fox Maule geothermal-heat-flux data. This function converts the geothermal-heat flux data from J s-1 m-2 to that used by CSLVR, J a-1 m-2.

This data is downloaded by executing the script cslvr_root/scripts/download_greenland_data.py

The keys of the dictionary returned by this function are :

  • q_geo – geothermal-heat flux
Return type:dict
static get_mouginot()[source]¶

Greenland velocity mosiac. This function creates a new data field with key mask that is 1 where velocity measurements are present and 0 where they are not.

You will have to contact the authors of that paper to get the data. When you download it from them, you can just put the .nc file named Greenland_ice_speed_v2017.nc in the root_dir/data/greenland directory.

The keys of the dictionary returned by this function are :

  • vx – \(x\)-component of velocity
  • vy – \(y\)-component of velocity
  • mask – observation mask
Return type:dict
static get_noel()[source]¶

Greenland surface-mass balance at 1km resolution averaged over the years (1958 – 2015).

You will have to download the data from the authors and manually place it in the cslvr_root_dir/data/greenland directory.

The keys of the dictionary returned by this function are :

  • S – surface topography height
  • mask – ice shelf mask (1 where ice, 0 where no ice)
  • smb – surface-mass balance in m.i.e. a^{-1}.
Parameters:thklim (float) – minimum-allowed ice thickness
Return type:dict
static get_rignot()[source]¶

Greenland Rignot surface velocity data. This function creates a new data field with key mask that is 1 where velocity measurements are present and 0 where they are not.

You will have to download the data from the authors and manually place it in the cslvr_root_dir/data/greenland directory.

The keys of the dictionary returned by this function are :

  • vx – \(x\)-component of velocity
  • vy – \(y\)-component of velocity
  • v_err – velocity error
  • mask – observation mask
Return type:dict
static get_searise(thklim=0.0)[source]¶

Greenland Searise data.

This function converts the geothermal-heat flux data from J s-1 m-2 to that used by CSLVR, J a-1 m-2, and the surface temperature data from degrees Celsius to degrees Kelvin.

This data is downloaded by executing the script cslvr_root/scripts/download_greenland_data.py

The keys of the dictionary returned by this function are :

  • B – basal surface height
  • S – upper surface height
  • T – surface temperature
  • lat – grid latitude
  • lon – grid longitude
  • adot – accumulation/ablation function
  • q_geo – geothermal-heat flux
  • dhdt – suface height rate of change
  • U_sar – surface velocity magnitude
Return type:dict

Accessing pre-built meshes : the MeshFactory class¶

Converting data to CSLVR format : the DataInput class¶

class inputoutput.DataInput(di, mesh=None, order=1)[source]¶

This class is used as a container for all geographical and geological data used by CSLVR, and posseses the ability to

  1. Remove rows or columns in sets that are entirely composed of nan’s (done automatically).
  2. Convert projections between datasets.
  3. Generate Expression objects to be used by Model instances
Parameters:
  • di (dict) – dictionary of data returned by one of the functions of DataFactory
  • mesh (Mesh) – finite-element mesh to use for generation of Expression’s, if desired
  • order (int) – if a mesh is used, this defines the order of the finite-element basis used by get_expression()

A number of class variables are generated by the instantiation of this class which may be useful. These are:

  • self.data – dict of data associated with DataFactory dict di
  • self.proj – projection Proj

Data projection \(x,y\) coordinates :

  • self.x – array of data grid \(x\)-coordinates
  • self.y – array of data grid \(y\)-coordinates
change_projection(di)[source]¶

Changes the Proj of this data to that of the di DataInput object’s Proj. The works only if the object was created with the parameter create_proj == True.

Parameters:di – the DataInput which contains the projection you would like to convert to
get_expression(fn, order=1, near=False)[source]¶

Creates a spline-interpolation expression for data with key fn with order of approximation in \(x\) and \(y\) directions order. if near == True, use nearest-neighbor interpolation.

Parameters:
  • fn (string) – key of data to form expression of
  • order (int) – order of the interpolation
  • near (bool) – use nearest-neighbor interpolation
get_xy(lon, lat)[source]¶

Returns the \((x,y)\) projection map coordinates corresponding to a given (lon,lat) coordinate pair using this DataInput object’s current projection self.proj.

Parameters:
  • lon (float, array) – longitude coordinate(s)
  • lat (float, array) – latitude coordinate(s)
interpolate_from_di(di, fi, fo, order=3)[source]¶

Interpolates the data field with key fi of another DataInput object di to the grid used by this object. Saves the resulting interpolation within this object’s self.data dictionary with key fo. Order may be any of:

  • 1 – nearest-neighbor interpolation
  • 2 – linear interpolation
  • 3 – cubic interpolation
Parameters:
  • di (DataInput) – the DataInput to interpolate from
  • fi (string) – the key of the data to interpolate from.
  • fo (string) – the key to save the data within self.data
  • order (int) – order of interpolation (see above).
reduce_size_to_box(ll_lon, ll_lat, ur_lon, ur_lat)[source]¶

Reduce the size of the data to the box with lower-left-corner coordinates (ll_lon, ll_lat) and upper-right-corner coordinates (ur_lon, ur_lat).

rescale_field(fo, fn, umin, umax, inverse=False)[source]¶

Rescale the data field of this instance with key fo to lower and upper bound umin, umax, creating a new data field in the process with key fn.

If inverse == True, scale the data to the inverse of data fo, i.e., the smallest values become umax, and the largest become umin.

This is useful, for example, when refining a mesh in areas where a velocity field is of highest magnitude.

Parameters:
  • fo (string) – key of the data to rescale
  • fn (string) – key of the new rescaled data
  • umin (float) – minimum value to rescale
  • umax (float) – maximum value to rescale
  • inverse (bool) – rescale the inverse of fo instead
set_data_max(fn, boundary, val)[source]¶

Set all values of the array associated with this instance’s self.data dictionary with key fn above boundary to value val.

Parameters:
  • fn (string) – key of data array
  • boundary (float) – boundary below which to assign
  • val (float) – boundary to assign
set_data_min(fn, boundary, val)[source]¶

Set all values of the array associated with this instance’s self.data dictionary with key fn below boundary to value val.

Parameters:
  • fn (string) – key of data array
  • boundary (float) – boundary below which to assign
  • val (float) – boundary to assign
set_data_val(fn, old_val, new_val)[source]¶

Set all values of the array associated with this instance’s self.data dictionary with key fn with value old_val to new_val.

Parameters:
  • fn (string) – key of data array
  • old_val (float) – the value to change
  • new_val (float) – the value to replace
transform_xy(di)[source]¶

Transforms the projection coordinates (di.x, di.y) of the DataInput object di to the projection used by this DataInput’s.

Parameters:di – the DataInput with projection coordinates to transform
Return type:tuple of converted coordinates
